review: Love it! However I have issues with it. Apps do crash from time to time, it goes into sleep mode too quickly when paused (probably need to find where to adjust that in the settings or something), and I don’t like not having the most recent whatever showing up on the home page (only Amazon content will show there, maybe another setting? Doubtful). Aside from these minor complaints, it works great! I have Hulu, Netflix, Disney, Prime (of course), and Apple TV accounts. They all work great. Very happy...but....I probably stared at the specs for the lite and regular one for no less than four hours before making the purchase. I knew everything was the same, but the difference between the two is clear: the lite requires you to use two separate remotes for volume and power for the TV, and is it worth $10 to have all that on the very sleek nice Firestick remote. Here is a break down of me living out my decision of trying out the lite:Day 1. I’m not that picky. I can have two remotes. Plus it’s in my home office, not a big room. No big deal.Day 2. Yep, I did lay the firestick remote by the tv and somehow left the other remote on the coach on the other side of the room. It’s just habit. I need to get used to putting them in the same place.Day 3. Why is this so hard to remember. This old remote for my TV doesn’t work very well. Maybe I should have went with the one with everything I need in one remote. It could have solved two problems, because of the aging TV remote. Hmmm.Day 4. Maybe I can duct tape the remotes together. There has to be some way to make this less painful. I’m really starting to regret this decision.Day 5. I’m not sure about any of the decisions I have ever made in my life if this is the type of decisions I am making. I have kids that were planned, maybe I’ve made all kinds of bad decisions that I have just been forcing myself to live with! How could I have not realized how much of a pain it is to keep these two remotes together. Why is that so hard, but now every time I have to hunt for one or the other it is like someone is punching me in the face with a $10 bill pasted to their knuckles. It’s the volume changing from all the office calls (or pausing or needing to do both or one of the other quickly) and sometimes it’s the boss so I can’t be running around the room trying to kill the sound before answering the call. This was a mistake, and I can solve it for $10. I’d pay $20 if I can escape the pain and suffering I have caused myself these five days which feels like five years!Day 6. Return initiated, extra $10 engaged, regular Firestick arrives tomorrow. It can’t get here fast enough! Now I’m cool with not having 4K because the only TVs I would use this on aren’t 4K and the one tv that is had its own apps (its smart like that, and it got a 1300 on the GRE, which is respectable). Let’s just breath and relax with the epiphany of one remote to rule them all, one remote to find them, one remote to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.Day 7. The one remote has become precious to me.So pay the $10. What do you need, ulcers?

Apart from the price savings, there isn't much to like about the Fire TV Stick Lite.I have a full fledged Fire TV 4k stick, as well as a Chromecast.I bought this Lite version as a sort of spare for screen mirroring (sometimes the screen mirroring function on the Chromecast can be persnickety).I thought the only features the Lite Stick would lack would be volume/power and as I am fine using two remotes, I thought, why not?Here's why -- the Fire TV Stick 4K with onboard on and off seems to "remember" which HDMI port it was connected to and to maintain the audio/video connection.Whereas the Lite Version "forgets." I often have to turn the TV on or off, or reboot the stick. It's a nuisance.To be honestly, I use both of my Fire TV sticks mostly for mirroring, rather than the onboard Fire TV interface, which I find isn't nearly as responsible and intuitive as using the Amazon Prime Video app on my phone or PC, then mirroring that app to the Fire TV stick.Also, I noticed there were more ads on the Fire TV Stick than there used to be. Yes, I know Prime has ads for paid video content, but since when do we see ads for completely unrelated products like insurance policies?  Very obnoxious.Anyhow, in terms of being able to maintain a mirrored connection, both Fire TV sticks are better at it than my Chromecast, which connects more easily, but occasionally has to be reconnected when the connection drops.However, the Fire TV sticks are much more troublesome in terms of establishing the initial screencast link. For starters, there isn't a shortcut. You have to use the remote to maneuver to the settings menu, select display, select screen mirroring or screen sharing, and then select screen mirroring or sharing on your phone.Really, the  best way by far to use Prime Video is via a hard-wired cable connection from your pc/ipad/iphone/android, if you have the appropriate cable and provided the device you are linking supports MHL video output (which fewer and fewer Android devices support these days).All that said, if wireless casting is your only option and if you absolutely need a solution that is ultra-cheap when it is on sale, the Fire TV Stick Lite does work, provided you have the patience to reconnect it and perhaps reboot it once in a while.Nevertheless, if you can spare a few bucks more, I recommend buying the fully-fledged Fire Stick 4k rather than the lite version.

I bought this to replace an old Roku that was giving me trouble, thought this would be an upgrade. Unfortunately, this is way more of a pain than the Roku has ever been. It almost never wants to play sound, which is incredibly irritating. I have to unplug it and plug it back in constantly, though that doesn’t even work most of the time unless I leave it unplugged for several hours or even days. It’s also a big pain to go back to a show you were watching. You have to click through all the channels, find the show, then try to figure out which one you were watching. It looks like you’ve already watched shows you didn’t see, the line across the bottom shows up on ones you never watched. If you were watching a series, most of the time it will jump several shows ahead so you have to go back and fast fwd through a bunch of episodes to figure out where you were. Sometimes it will randomly start playing in the middle of an episode you haven’t watched when you turn it on. I bought Discovery+ through this and can’t access it through my Roku, so it’s annoying when I want to finish a show but can’t get any sound. With everything technology is capable of these days, it’s amazing that not even the most basic things (like sound) will work. Too late to return it. Glad I at least bought it on sale since it’ll likely end up in the garbage. For now I’m back to using the old Roku as even that works way better than this thing. Extremely disappointing! I will just buy another Roku in the future. The idea and ability to get many different channels is great, if they could only get it to work consistently and fix some of the annoyances. Not worth having to keep unplugging it and plugging it back in several times just to hear the sound. Today I’ve done that 6 times and it still won’t work. At least my Roku plays sound.

This is my first streaming Stick, I've previously used Roku stand alone devices. I did not need TV on/off or volume control etc so I went with the Lite. The main reasons for buying the Stick are: to evaluate the Fire user interface and try the Silk browser (Roku does not support a browser).The Stick was connected at the back of my AV receiver (using the supplied extension cord) within an AV cabinet, a less than ideal situation. Despite the Stick being surrounded by a jumble of receiver wires, that you might expect to effect RF signal strength, the remote worked fine and I obtained a Very Good WiFi signal indication.Stick setup was easy. The Fire homepage is arranged differently to Roku but is no less usable. The only omission is a complete lack of time & date info on the homepage or screensaver, something I'm used to with the Roku. The speed of operation is similar to Roku.The Silk browser works great. I use it to navigate to radio station homepages and bookmark the URL. While on the subject of radio stations, the Fire TV TuneIn app is not as comprehensive as either the Roku or Kindle tablet versions, with a lack of Recents and Favorites. However, the Fire TV iHeart Radio app is better than the Roku or Kindle tablet (go figure?) versions but it still lacks several local major stations. So between using Silk and iHeart I'm able get all the stations I need.The ESPN app took two attempts to load (load, fail-to-start, uninstall, re-load) but eventually worked fine. So far I'm impressed with the hardware and I've managed to overcome any software imitations.

After evaluating several streaming devices, I’ve determined the Firestick is my best option with the most features and performance for a reasonable price. Especially with this new 2020 release, it performs faster and with fewer glitches than previous gens. I recently focused on the TiVo Stream 4K because I liked the way their search engine would aggregate content from all streaming sources, so you wouldn’t have to search individually through Netflix, Hulu, Apple+, Amazon Prime, etc. to try to find a movie.But guess what? Amazon has incorporated a new search that will do the same thing with this new release! If you notice, TiVo is so nervous about this they quickly dropped the price on their Stream 4K from $49 down to $39.....for BROKEN hardware. Read on.The main focus of my testing is surround sound capabilities. I use an OTG (On The Go) micro USB cable to plug in my thumb drives to the Firestick. I am then able to play my 5.1 audio files encoded as Dolby Digital AC3, DTS, FLAC, WAV, SACD-DST etc. Firestick DOES PLAY and properly decode all of these via the terrific “Kodi” player app. TiVo’s Stream 4K also plays these files, but even though it DISPLAYS a 5.1 Dolby Digital+ decode it is REALLY only playing in just TWO CHANNELS! Even a standard stereo two channel mp3 shows being played back as full Dolby Digital+ 5.1....FAIL!But the problem with the Amazon Firestick is its inability to read anything other than FAT32 formatted drives natively. EVERY other streaming device I’ve tested can read NTFS drives natively. Yes, there is a workaround by playing files through the “ES File Explorer” app that then plays through Kodi, but you can’t sequence playlists, and for each file you need to hit the home button to get back to the ES app to then load another file....NO GOOD!The other big issue with FAT32: files are limited to 4.2 gigs in size. FAT32 cannot read anything larger. So if you have a movie larger than 4.2GB you’re out of luck. So outdated.Amazon crew members, get on the “Stick” and add native NTFS support!

I also have a 4k stick for the main living room tv and this actually seems a little quicker than it. Setup was easy, though you do have to be patient while it first downloads and updates during the setup process. There were a couple of times I thought it gave up, only to have it suddenly continue on. Anyone that's still using an old 1st gen I strongly suggest upgrading. You won't be sorry!

Tough. Unless you want them blasting in your ears at full volume you need headphones with on board volume control. Now if you have headphones with on board volume control they will work but they will sound like utter crap and in my case the audio only comes out of the left channel (skullcandy wireless headphones). It also pops, cracks and cuts out every 10-30 seconds and has insane audio lag that constantly changes, so expect to mess with your TVs lip sync feature (if it has one) about 2-5 times and hour. I’ve also tried to connect a Bose Mini BT speaker. It connects but has the same pop/click issue. I tried using the aux-in on the Bose and my TVs audio out with zero sound. So enjoy your crappy tv speakers.The video: the video quality is pretty awful. I get weird red scan lines and all sorts of other glitches. It has major frame rate drops...I’m sorry why does this piece of crap exist from one of the biggest tech companies in the world? And every new version seems to be worse. Or it will start and then give a message about "can't find" or "can't connect to that service at this time". Or it asks me to login to the services again. In both cases making it restart fixes it for a while. Sometimes Echo Dot can control it, sometimes it says I should go back to the Alexa app.This one is supposed to be the one without TV? Or maybe not replace the TV's remote. I don't know. I don't need either.It's the layout of the buttons. Logically the Home button should be at the top or the bottom (larger?) so you don't have to look to press it. No, they put it up from the bottom, between other buttons so I have to look each time. I've been using this a few months now.Pros (when it works):1. It streams some apps better and faster than the same apps via smart TV.2. Alexa's voice recognition has a pretty high accuracy, though there's room for improvement.3. The device is easy to set up.4. It's a good workaround for older TVs with specs too outdated for some channels, like iMDB TV.Cons (here we go):1. No disabling/adjusting sleep mode. Amazon refuses to add an option to turn OFF sleep mode, despite being given legit use cases for doing so in Amazon forums for the last couple of years. Want to leave it on for pets when you go out? Forget it. Have a business where the display needs to remain on? Nope. Or maybe you're like me and forget the TV is on because the screen is black. CAN I JUST SAY HOW ANNOYING THIS IS? You either have to root it, or install a 3rd party app (some of which also disable the screen saver).2. Interface text is SMALL. Like, really, REALLY unnecessarily, stupidly small. The last update did this, and there was no functional reason for it, just a designer decision of aesthetics over user need. So I guess older users, those with distance vision issues, or who have to place the TV a distance away don't matter.3. Given the brief time I've had it, I've had to restart it more often than I should have to. Captions will stop syncing up, audio will go out, or the video will freeze. This is while using Prime or Netflix, which BTW doesn't happen when I use the same apps installed on my Smart TV.4. The controller is small and very black, so it's super easy to lose, especially if you watch TV in low light or have dark furniture. I've had to add bits of fluorescent duct tape and glow tape so I can find them easier (or you can buy a brightly-colored silicone skin for it). And it's too curved to be able to stick any kind of location tag to it.I bought two, so obviously I didn't hate it. But this lack of responsiveness to good use cases and making changes nobody asked for that makes it less user- friendly are real issues.UPDATE: 4 months in and one is already broken. How convenient, when the warranty is 90 days.After about a minute, the screen freezes, and then the Fire Stick powers itself off completely! (Tried clearing the cache, soft reboot, hard reboot, restart the TV, even a factory reset - and problem persists.) Really, REALLY disappointing. Before this happened, I was seriously considering an Amazon Echo. Forget THAT.

I have a generation 1 FireStick. I didn't use it much, it was so sluggish to move from menu to menu. Since I'm now working from home, I decided to monitor my surveillance cameras with the Firestick.  I have 5 1 megapixel cameras, and have 2 different programs I can use: tinyCam Monitor PRO and Onvifer Pro.I use these 2 interchangeably on my Note 8 with no troubles.  The cameras are on my lan, so the internet is out of the picture.The Firestick (gen 1) was not up to the task, video sometimes would freeze, it was never smooth, and was pretty much always pixelating on any motion or just crashing, so I decided to upgrade to the latest gen of Firestick.  This device is MUCH smoother moving between menus, and is a much more enjoyable experience than the earlier version. The surveillance camera software is much better, its usable for the most part, still some choppiness and alot of lag, so I was disappointed with that, and they only crash once or twice in 8 hours.  The device sits 4 feet from the wireless source, and its a 5g link, checking the connection reveals no connection problems, and can't be the source of the lag, so that points to hardware.  Plex seems to work better on this one better than the original one.  Overall, its an improvement over gen 1, and perhaps I don't use it as intended, since I don't use it for entertainment, but I expected better performance.

Tv in living room. Had just got cable but didn’t have the channels I wanted without paying some outrageous price. Was recommended by a friend. The video we watch was horrible. Still don’t know all the features because it was hard to follow the video.

I'm still unsure. I have a very good surround system centered on a Denon AVR and multiple speakers.  All my surround sources go to the AVR which handles the surround audio and the video is sent to an LG OLED TV.  I want to be able to watch HBO Max movies in surround and initially bought a Chromecast which is supposed to be able to do surround but could not get it to work.  Saw many comments online having the same problems.  Spoke to their support but no joy.  Returned the Chromecast and bought this and it works PERFECTLY!!  I didn't want TV volume control as I have a universal remote to take care of that so this Fire Stick Lite is perfect.  The only down side is that the Fire Stick remote is not IR  so I cannot have my universal remote (which is IR only) control it.  But other than that it works very well.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED if you want surround audio.

This is my third Firestick.  I bought it because it was the latest generation and my first generation had trouble with a couple of apps - dropping video, and audio not synced with video.  This corrected that problem (so far) but now every so often I get no audio.  The only way to fix this is to unplug the power to the transmitter for a couple of minutes to allow it to reboot.  Then, so far, the audio will come back on.  Not sure if this is a problem with just my device or if it might be inherent to all devices.  Other than that it works OK.Since my last review:Got two separate phone calls from Amazon.  The first was to verify that I had connected the device properly and to try different router settings.  This did not help.  But I did find that if I turned off the TV and then turned it back on most to the time the audio would then work.  On the second call from Amazon, they asked for all of the info regarding model of TV, etc., as they had similar concerns from other customers.A couple of days later another annoying problem came up.  During the playing of a video on the You Tube app, the video suddenly froze.  Tried turning on/off the TV with no success.  Tried other apps and they worked OK.  Opened You Tube on a different Firestick and a different TV and it worked OK.  Went back to this one and it still froze up.  Finally removed the power and unplugged from the HDMI port, let sit for about a minute, reconnected to the TV and then the You Tube app started playing again.  This is getting very annoying.  Hope Amazon can come up with a solution soon.1/27/21 - Amazon replaced this item with a "reconditioned firestick."  Within 4-5 days it started exhibiting the same problems.  Evidently this item was probably returned for the same problems, then marked "reconditioned" and sent to me as a replacement.  I've have spent countless hours on the phone with Amazon service reps, along with countless hours reconfiguring and then having to drive 70 miles to a UPS store to return the previous item.  Looks like I will be going through the same hassle again.  If Amazon would have just replaced this item with a new item possibly out of a better batch, I wouldn't continue having this problem.

I am old, old, old "school" and do not use the voice recognition feature.  I'm a button-kind-of-guy, but the fewer the better, and this one is just right, EXCEPT for a couple of features.  First, of course, you need a good quality (does not mean expensive) streaming TV and Internet.  Quality of ours (Roku) is pretty good.  The features I do NOT like are:The size of the remote/stick might be OK for a child's hand but it is difficult for man hands.  It is also super slick, like slide-out-of-my-hand slick.  Lastly from me, the volume control on the side is awkward to use, and there is an echo/feedback situation competing with our sound bar unless I put this remote on mute.  Even then, I or someone else sometimes inadvertently touch the up/down volume buttons and have to hit mute again if I notice the interference with the TV sound bar.  Functionally, the device works great (and there are a lot of programming choices), but the design of the handheld REALLY needs improvement.

I have a Vizio M55-D0.The only port this device fits in is the Side HDMI as the shape of the TV back prevents a direct plug in. Using the side HDMI port I get HDCP error immediately upon playing any video, the menus work fine, but zero content will play.I overcame this by purchasing a 90" elbow to plug this into the rear HDMI port (there is no flex connector or adapter in the package for compatibility issues fyi). Now most video plays... Strangely when I purchase explicit content (PPV, ESPN+ non-prime, non-netflix) I get HDCP errors that come up every few minutes show for a few seconds and then disappear - this pains me because I'm trying to enjoy purchased content, and usually hosting guests when doing so.Thought I could work through this will ROKU support. They send you instructions similar to the initial step 1 of calling the your internet provided in the early 2000s. Have you tried turning it off and on, then also unplugging and then plugging it back in again (to each HDMI port on the TV) - yup.Maybe I have older tech or something, but it plain doesn't work consistently for copyright issues, not necessarily the device not working - which is painful because it seems the device is nice, but the content cannot be delivered.2016 year model TV and 2018/19 Roku just won't play well together

This is my third Roku, and it's the first one with a remote problem.  Presumably it's because it's now a stick instead of a box, so it's plugged into the back of my stereo receiver.  The remote was unreliable out of the box, and when I checked on the Roku website I was told to order a free "extension cord" for the Roku, to get it away from the HDMI ports.  That has only helped a bit. Every time I turn on the stereo and Roku, the remote is unworkable for a while.  I keep pushing buttons and then all of a sudden it's good.  But then later on it might stop working again.  I checked the batteries in case they sent me some that were nearly dead, but the meter says they are good.Why is Roku selling a device that supposedly has a long-distance RF remote when the RF signal apparently isn't strong enough to overcome interference?  The Fire TV stick plugged in next to it has no remote problems at all.  I may return this.

The Roku SS+ was easy to pair to my TV and could power it on and off, and adjust the TV speaker volume. However, I was disappointed that I was not able to get the Roku remote to control my Sonos playbar which is hooked up to my LG TV via optical out. Prior to purchase I called Roku to make sure the remote could control my TV and Sonos. They told me that if my TV supported Consumer Electronics Control (CEC), I'd be fine. But they were wrong. My hours of googling suggested that If you use ARC over HDMI to connect your sound bar to your TV, Roku TV can use CEC to control the sound bar’s volume (maybe). First off, I want to be clear that activation of the Roku device is free. Purchasing the device is the only money you pay to Roku. If you have somehow end up on a website claiming that you have to pay them an activation fee or an upgrade fee just to be able to use your Roku device then you have navigated to the wrong address and it is a scam. What you do have to pay for, if you choose to do so, is any of the paid subscription streaming services you want. Some services require a paid subscription and some don't. To name a few:  Watching basic YouTube (the same ones you watch for free on your phone, tablet, or computer), Tubi TV, Pluto TV, and hoopla (if available through your public library) are all free of charge. Netflix, Amazon Video, CBS All Access, YouTube TV, and Apple TV+ charge a monthly fee, but that has nothing to do with whether or not you use a Roku device to access their content.We bought a TCL Roku TV a couple years ago and, between Netflix and Prime, found that we weren't watching cable television anymore.  So we downgraded to internet-only service through our cable provider and got this stick for our bedroom TV.Unlike some of the less expensive Roku offerings, the remote that comes with this one does both TV power and volume, so as long as you're getting all your content through Roku (and never need to switch inputs to, say, cable/satellite/antenna service or a DVD player) you don't need to have a separate TV remote.  I was surprised the remote doesn't have a mute button, though.  Our TCL Roku TV's remote had such a button.  So if you're a heavy user of the mute button you may find that this does not in fact save you from needing a separate TV remote. I'm also a little troubled that our Roku TV, which we bought new only about two years ago, doesn't support Apple TV+. This particular streaming stick does support it. But it seems like a couple years is way too early for a streaming device to be even starting to creep into obsolescence. I have no interest in buying a new Roku stick every few years, and hope this isn't a sign of what's to come.It's also clear that the Roku stick has no idea whether the TV is on or off.  This means that if you just push the power button in the middle of watching something, it will keep playing--and perhaps even advance automatically to the next show.  This means you'll lose your place in a series and, perhaps more importantly, will consume more power and data.  So remember to stop playback when you turn off the TV.  Or get one of those power strips that automatically turns off accessories when the master device turns off. (Or buy a Roku TV instead of a separate TV and Roku stick--but remember my comment above about sliding into obscelescence.)If you're looking for free entertainment, there are some options but you probably won't find them up to par with paid cable TV or perhaps even with free over-the-air TV.  Tubi has some content, including a "Not on Netflix" section.  Pluto TV is okay--it has a lot of channels, but they're largely underwhelming.  There's a local news "channel" that in our case gives us content for the nearest big city, an hour away, rather than our actual local news stations.  The Roku Channel occasionally has a movie worth watching.  Your public library may offer some content through Hoopla as well. So there are some free options, but you're unlikely to be completely satisfied without some form of paid entertainment.

I put a tv on our patio and was worried about running cable through the walls (brick). Such a fuss!  I read on all the different streaming devices and chose the Roku because it has an Xfinity app which is our cable provider. We can now sit on the patio and watch all of our channels and no wires through the wall!  Also, the Roku just plugs into the USB on the tv!  No need for a power supply but I’m glad it came with one and you didn’t have to pay extra for it!  I plan on getting another for our projector to have movie night in the back yard!I had trouble at first getting a solid connection to the internet. Signal would drop and movies would pause to buffer. I decided to upgrade my router. Wow!  Big difference!  It wasn’t the Roku at all!  The Nighthawk router cured that. Will also do my review on the Nighthawk too!The stream stick is larger than most but I had no problem using a different HDMI port. However, if you do have problems with plugging it up, they will send you an HDMI cable for free. So, either way, you’re covered.About the apps- yes, I bought the Roku because it has an app from my cable provider. Yet, that doesn’t mean that you can’t use it if you’re not with Xfinity. There are plenty other cable tv apps available!  Additionally, you can simply load the channel app that you want. I also enjoy the free tv apps like Pluto TV. Older movies but good ones and plenty to choose from!A built in web browser would make this unit complete!  Still won’t prevent a 5 star rating, though. I have used old desktops for years to connect to projectors and TV’s in my home and shop. The space savings is incredible - going from a desktop to a device the size of a USB jump drive!!  Not to mention the power savings!!We love it!

So here is the deal. I already have a Roku Streaming Stick 3600R (2016 version) in our family room. We liked it so much that we wanted our kids to have it for their play area TV, which was closer to the router. Since the family room now needed a new streaming device, I decided to go with the next logical step, the Roku Streaming Stick+ 3810.I am not new to the Roku experience and interface. It was still very snappy. The great content apps were still there. It's basically waiting for me to do a TV upgrade to 4K, which I don't know when it's going to happen. :)I also did discover that I can actually turn on/off the power to my Sony sound bar and also control its volume using only the Roku remote. This makes it very convenient.To feel good about this upgrade, I decided to do several tests related to the temperature, Wi-Fi signal (both using Roku secret menus) and then a speed test using Netflix. I know the Netflix test is not a pure speed test because it uses the Netflix servers, but it's an acceptable indicator for me.Please keep in mind that this is not a scientific test. It's more of a test to check for systematic changes between the two Rokus given other fixed factors. I did all testing within the span of 1-2 hours so I hope no major changes were introduced that affected the tests.Test Configuration (things that did not change during testing): - I did *not* change any advanced default settings in the Roku devices (e.g. interference mitigation, power, etc.) - For audio/video, Roku devices were connected via HDMI to a Sony sound bar HT-CT380, *not* directly into the TV. Both the sound bar and TV support only 1080p, not 4K. - For power, Roku devices were connected to Dish Network Hopper 3 receiver's USB port, which is nice because it is on all the time, whether Hopper is powered on or in standby. - For Wi-Fi, Roku devices were connected wirelessly to a Netgear Nighthawk R7000 (with custom Tomato Shibby firmware) which supports both bands: 2.4 and 5.0 GHz.Test Results*** Roku Streaming Stick (3600) ***Temperature: 74 C2.4 GHz Signal strength: 252.4 GHz Antenna 1: 292.4 GHz Antenna 2: 32Glitch/sec: 385.0 GHz Signal strength: 195.0 GHz Antenna 1: 175.0 GHz Antenna 2: 19Glitch/sec: 32.4 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 14.87 Mbps5.0 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 15.63 Mbps*** Roku Streaming Stick+ (3810) ***Temperature: 97 C2.4 GHz Signal strength: 212.4 GHz Antenna 1: 322.4 GHz Antenna 2: 34Glitch/sec: 1775.0 GHz Signal strength: 285.0 GHz Antenna 1: 345.0 GHz Antenna 2: 32Glitch/sec: 02.4 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 35.58 Mbps5.0 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 75.13 MbpsConclusions: - Roku 3810 runs about ~30% hotter than the Roku 3600. I hope it's still within acceptable range. I did not receive any warnings or anything during use. - With Roku 3810, 2.4 GHz overall Signal Strength decreased by ~16% compared to Roku 3600. - With Roku 3810, 5.0 GHz overall Signal Strength improved by ~47% compared to Roku 3600. - With Roku 3810, 2.4 Ghz Netflix connection speed improved by an impressive ~139% compared to Roku 3600. - With Roku 3810, 5.0 Ghz Netflix connection speed improved by an incredible ~380% compared to Roku 3600.Comments: - I noticed in one of the tests that the while the Antennas (1 and 2) signal strengths were higher, the overall Signal Strength was lower. Perhaps the overall Signal Strength takes into account other factors such as  glitch/sec, interference, etc.? I am not really sure. - Even though 2.4 GHz signal was poorer with the new Roku, I still got faster speeds with Netflix. This tells me that not only the antennas are different, but perhaps the Wi-Fi chipset is improved or something. - In general, using 2.4 GHz band produced way more glitches per second compared to 5.0 GHz, so in my situation, I recommend/prefer using the 5.0 GHz band, especially considering the speed test results in Netflix.Overall, I feel happy about the experience.
